responses: The contamination event occurred on or around December 1, 2002.
Soderhamn municipality

The contamination event was associated with consumption of communal water (CW) and was linked to two outbreaks of Campylobacter and acute gastroenteritis (AGI) in the Soderhamn municipality in December 2002 and January 2003.
The text does not provide any information on what triggered the contamination event.
The origin of the contamination was identified as the routine well water sample with one E. coli that was analysed two weeks prior to the investigation.

The contamination event was first discovered through a rapid assessment based on 750 telephone interviews indicating that 24% of the population self-reported AGI, potentially affecting some 6-7000 members of the population.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant was 6-7000.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 6-7000.
The attack rate for individuals who became ill was 27.3% (95% CI: 23.1-31.5%).
The study did not provide information on fatalities associated with the contamination event.
Campylobacter was found in stool, environmental, and water samples.

The study found that cases of Campylobacter infection were more likely than referents to consume communal water (OR = 12.6 (95% CI 1.7-92.3)). In the cohort study, risk of gastroenteritis was 2.3 times higher in those who consumed water (AR = 27.3%) than others (AR = 12%). Risk of illness was associated with the amount of water consumed in both studies.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included intensification of water sampling; chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality; and holding a press conference to inform the population.

The investigation included:

1. Intensification of water sampling
2. Chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality
3. Holding a press conference to inform the population.
4. No advice on boiling water was issued.
The case definition for the cohort study was defined as a person living in the Soderhamn municipality during December 2002 and January 2003 with self-diagnosed acute gastrointestinal illness (AGI).

Risk factors identified during the investigation include:
1. Consumption of communal water (OR = 12.6, 95% CI = 1.7-92.3)
2. Amount of water consumed (RR = 27.3%, 95% CI = 12-56)
The contamination event spanned a period of 59 days, from December 1, 2002 until January 28, 2003.
Intensification of water sampling; chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality; holding a press conference to inform the population; no advice on boiling water was issued.
Water analyses methods performed during the monitoring phase included standard methods at Gavle Hospital and SMI laboratories respectively.

The epidemiological investigations included intensification of water sampling; chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality; holding a press conference to inform the population; and no advice on boiling water was issued.

The County Medical Officer (CMO) for Gavleborg noticed an increased incidence of domestic, laboratory confirmed cases of Campylobacter in the municipality of Soderhamn. As a prevention measure, intensification of water sampling was implemented, chlorination of the water supplies of the municipality was carried out, and a press conference was held to inform the population about the outbreak. No advice on boiling water was issued.

responses: The event occurred on or around March 29, 2016.
The contamination event took place in Cheptui River.

The contamination event was a cholera outbreak that occurred in Bwikhonge Sub-county, Bulambuli District in Eastern Uganda. The outbreak started on 29th February and sharply increased in late March. The cases were identified through active case finding and laboratory testing. The index case had onset on 29th February but the outbreak had been ongoing in neighboring sub-counties for the previous 3 months. V. cholera was isolated in 2 of the 7 river water samples collected from different locations. The contamination event was caused by drinking contaminated water from Cheptui River.
The contamination event was triggered by the index case in Bwikhonge Sub-county.
The investigation identified that the contamination source was Cheptui River water.
The contamination event was first discovered through active case finding by visiting all parishes in Bwikhonge Sub-county with the help of members of community health workers.
The study found that 8404 individuals were exposed to contaminated water from Cheptui River during the outbreak period.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 108 suspected cases (attack rate: 1.3%, 108/8404).
The attack rate for this cholera outbreak was 1.3% (108/8404).
The study did not provide any information on fatality count associated with the contamination event.
Vibrio cholerae was isolated from 2 of the 7 river water samples collected from different locations.
The symptoms associated with contamination were sudden onset of watery diarrhea.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were:

1. Conducted a case-control study involving 100 suspected case-patients and 100 asymptomatic controls, individually-matched by residence village and age.
2. Collected seven water samples for laboratory testing.

The investigation included the following steps:

1. Defining a suspected case as sudden onset of watery diarrhea from March 1st, 2016 onwards in a resident of Bulambuli District.

2. Conducting a case-control study involving 100 suspected case-patients and 100 asymptomatic controls, individually-matched by residence village and age.

3. Collecting seven water samples for laboratory testing from different water sources within the affected communities, including two from borehole pumps, one from a swamp, and four from Cheptui River.

4. Culturing 13 stool samples collected from suspected cholera case-persons to confirm the cholera diagnosis.

5. Measuring the associations between drinking water exposure sources and cholera illness using the Mantel-Haenszel method to estimate odds ratios (OR) and their confidence intervals, accounting for pair-matching of cases and controls.
The case definition used for the cohort study is: "A suspected case is a resident of Bwikhonge Sub-county, Bulambuli District, who has sudden onset of watery diarrhea from 1 March 2016 onwards."

Risk factors identified during the investigation were:

1. Drinking contaminated water from Cheptui River.
The contamination event spanned from 1 March 2016 to 9 April 2016.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of contamination included boiling and/or treating drinking water, improved sanitation, distribution of chlorine tablets to affected villages, and construction of more borehole pumps as a long-term solution.

During the monitoring phase, bacteriological culture identification of V. cholerae was performed using stool samples collected from suspected cholera case-persons. Additionally, water samples were collected from different water sources within the affected communities (including 2 from borehole pumps, 1 from a swamp, and 4 from Cheptui River) for bacteriological culture identification of V. cholerae.
V. cholerae

The following steps were taken to restore the system after some time passed:

1. Boiling and/or treating drinking water
2. Improved sanitation
3. Distribution of chlorine tablets to the affected villages
4. Construction of more borehole pumps

The following measures have been implemented to prevent future contamination events: Boiling and/or treating drinking water, improved sanitation, distribution of chlorine tablets to the affected villages, and as a long-term solution, construction of more borehole pumps.

responses: The contamination event occurred in September 2000.
The contamination event took place at the service reservoir located on the upper part of the housing estate.

The contamination event described in the passage is an outbreak of Campylobacter jejuni infection that occurred in a South Wales Valleys housing estate. The outbreak was associated with tap water consumption and residence in the upper estate, where the majority of cases were reported. The likely cause of the outbreak was a crack in the wall of the holding reservoir that supplied mains water to the upper estate, allowing contamination with surface water from nearby pasture land.
Crack in the wall of the holding reservoir.
The likely cause of this outbreak was identified as contamination with surface water from nearby pasture land.
The contamination event was first discovered when a crack in the wall of the holding reservoir was identified.
The total number of individuals exposed to the contaminant was 690 households or 1770 individuals.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 15.
The attack rate for those resident in the upper estate was 232/802 (29.0%) compared with 1152 for those in the lower estate [relative risk (RR) 2.44, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.83-3.24, P<0.001].
The text does not provide information on fatality counts associated with the contamination event.
Campylobacters were found in the collected samples.
Diarrhea

Initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event included:

* Identification of the source of contamination (a crack in the wall of the holding reservoir)
* Investigation by the local government environmental health department
* Collection of information on individual's self-reported exposure to household pets and farm animals
* Collection of dietary history including specific questions on meats, meat products, takeaway meals, milk, carbonated drinks, tea/coffee, tap water and bottled water
* Assignment of source of mains tap water by whether they were resident in the upper or lower estate
* Collection of data on any history of diarrhoeal illness amongst residents or pets and dates and symptoms recorded
* Nested case-control study of laboratory-confirmed cases and estate resident controls that had not experienced diarrhoeal illness (simple random sample of 10% of cohort)

The detailed investigation or inspection that was conducted included:
* Bacteriological and chlorination records of weekly sampling of the service reservoir were provided by the water company and evaluated by the outbreak control team.
* Sampling of the service reservoir supplying the upper estate was carried out daily from 30 September by the water company and samples were tested for indicator organisms (coliforms and E. coli) and free and total chlorine levels.
* Additional analyses for faecal streptococci and clostridia were also performed.
The case definition used for the cohort study is: "An individual residing on the estate, with diarrhoeal illness (o3 stools within 24 h) lasting over 1 day in September 2000."

Risk factors identified during the investigation were:

1. Water consumption
2. Residence in the upper estate
3. Exposure to farm animals and pets
4. Consumption of takeaway meals and milk
5. Purchase of milk from a dairy supplying the milkman
The contamination event spanned from September 17-24, 2000.

The immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of contamination were:

1. Repairing and commissioning permanent booster chlorination facilities on 29 November 2000.

Water analyses methods performed during the monitoring phase included bacteriological and chlorination records of weekly sampling of the service reservoir, sampling of the service reservoir supplying the upper estate on daily basis from 30 September by the water company and tested for indicator organisms (coliforms and E. coli) and free and total chlorine levels. Additional analyses for faecal streptococci and clostridia were also performed.

responses: The contamination event occurred on March 6, 1981.
Eagle-Vail, Colorado

The contamination event was a waterborne nonbacterial gastroenteritis outbreak that occurred in Eagle-Vail, Colorado in March 1981. The outbreak was associated with rotavirus and was caused by a combination of factors including inadequate treatment of sewage at the local sewage treatment plant, lack of pre-treatment of water prior to filtration at the water treatment plant, severely channeled filter beds at the plant, and a failed chlorinator.

The upstream Vail Water & Sanitation District sewage treatment plant could not handle the load being presented to it and was discharging sludge solids into Gore Creek, upstream from the Eagle River water intake for the Eagle-Vail plant.
Rotavirus was identified as the origin of the contamination.

The contamination event was first discovered on Friday, March 13, 1981, when several citizens independently alerted the Colorado Department of Health to a possible outbreak of gastrointestinal disease in Eagle-Vail and Avon.
56 (43.8 per cent) of the 128 residents were exposed to the contaminant.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 56 (43.8 per cent) out of 128 residents.
Attack rate = 43.8%
Fatalities associated with the contamination event were zero (0).
Rotavirus was found in five of seven persons associated with the outbreak.
Diarrhea and/or vomiting were associated with the contamination.

The investigation included inspections of the water treatment plant at Eagle-Vail and the sewage treatment plant at Vail, as well as a survey of residents regarding their water consumption habits and any symptoms of illness they may have experienced.
The case definition used for the cohort study was diarrhea (three or more loose stools per day) and/or vomiting (at least once per day) during the previous 30 days.

Risk factors identified during the investigation were:

* Amount of tap water consumption
* No chemical or physical pre-treatment of water prior to filtration (no coagulation or polymer addition) at the Eagle-Vail water treatment plant
* Severely channeled filter beds were found in the water treatment plant at Eagle-Vail
* Failure of the Eagle-Vail chlorinator for an undetermined period of up to 24 hours ending March 5
The contamination event spanned from March 6-13.

The following immediate actions were taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination:
* The water treatment plant at Eagle-Vail and the sewage treatment plant at Vail were inspected within a few days after the outbreak came to attention.
* Forty-eight households were reached, with 128 residents, of whom over 80% were adults. All but five residents were over two years old and only a handful were over age 50.

The following types of water analyses methods were performed during the monitoring phase:

* Virus detection or serological methods (e.g., rotavirus)
* Electron microscopy (EM) for virus particles
* Radioimmunoassay (RIA) for antibody to rotavirus and Norwalk virus
* Heatlabile and heat-stable enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli testing at the Centers for Disease Control.
Rotavirus was detected using virus detection or serological methods.

* Emergency repairs to the Eagle-Vail water treatment plant cost $92,400 in the 30 days after the outbreak.
* Improvements to ensure a reliable safe water supply were made over the next 18 months at a cost of over $1 million.
Rotavirus should be looked for as a cause of waterborne outbreaks.
Individuals aged over two years old and only a handful were over age 50.

responses: The contamination event occurred between 11 and 22 October 1996.
The contamination event took place at the water distribution system.
The contamination event was caused by groundwater contamination of the water system. The water system used groundwater from a single borehole as one source and was not regularly chlorinated.
Groundwater contamination triggered the contamination event.
The origin of the contamination was identified as groundwater from a single borehole as one source used by the community water system.

The contamination event was first discovered on the second day of the outbreak (13 October) when the Laboratory of Hygiene collected three samples from the water distribution system, one sample from the tank, and one sample from the pumping station.
The number of individuals exposed to the contaminant is 2888 (288 cases x 10 individuals per case).
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 288.

Shigella sonnei was isolated from both, water samples and faeces of patients.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were diarrhea and vomiting.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were:
* Collected three samples from the water distribution system, one sample from the tank, and one sample from the pumping station on the first day after the outbreak had been recognized (11 October 1996).
* Collected a 1-l sample from the pumping station on 13 October.

The investigation included collecting water samples from the water distribution system, tank, and pumping station on the first day after recognition of the outbreak (11 October). Additional water samples were collected over the next 15 days. The samples were tested for the presence of Salmonella and Shigella using an enrichment technique with sterile 0-1% peptone water and serological identification was performed using slide agglutination technique with Shigella antisera (polyvalent and type-specific sera).
The case definition for the cohort study was based on self-reported illness among residents of Eleoussa, and included patients who experienced diarrhea and/or vomiting between 11 and 22 October 1996.

Risk factors identified during the investigation were:
* Age group 0-14 years (41.4%)
* Patients over 65 years were more frequently hospitalized than those in other age groups (P<0.05).
The contamination event spanned from 11 October 1996 to 22 October 1996.
Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of the contamination included an immediate chlorination of the water distribution system and the tank.

The following water analyses methods were performed during the monitoring phase:
* Membrane filtration method for total and faecal coliforms
* Enrichment technique with sterile 0-1% peptone water for the presence of salmonella and shigella
* Slide agglutination technique with shigella antisera (polyvalent and type-specific sera) for serological identification of shigella.
Shigella sonnei

• Immediate chlorination of the water distribution system and the tank.
The implementation of regular chlorination of the water system and the tank was considered as one of the most important prevention measures.

responses: The contamination event occurred between the end of August and the first half of October 2018.
The contamination event took place in the municipalities located along the Chiese river in the Brescia province of northern Italy.

The contamination event occurred in September 2018 in Brescia province, northern Italy, and resulted in 33 cases of Legionnaires' disease (LD), including two fatalities, residing in seven municipalities along the Chiese river. Water samples were collected from private homes, municipal water systems, cooling towers, and the river, and only three samples, all collected from the Chiese river, were positive for Lp2 ST1455. The environmental investigation was undertaken immediately, and the source of infection was identified as the Chiese river and its irrigation canals.
The text does not provide information on what triggered the contamination event.
The source of contamination was identified as the Chiese river and its irrigation canals located in the municipalities where most of the cases occurred.

The contamination event was first discovered through environmental investigations immediately after the outbreak was reported. Water samples were collected from private homes, municipal water systems, cooling towers, and the river Chiese, and were analysed for the presence of Lp. Of these, only three samples, all collected from the Chiese river, were Lp2 ST1455.
The total number of individuals exposed to the contaminant was 88.
The number of people who fell ill due to the event was 33.
The attack rate for this outbreak was 6.4% (34/533).
Two fatalities were associated with the contamination event.
Lp2 was identified and typed as sequence type 1455.
The symptoms associated with the contamination were pneumonia.

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were:
* An environmental investigation was undertaken immediately and water samples were collected from private homes, municipal water systems, cooling towers and the river. Overall, 533 environmental water samples were analysed and 34 were positive for Lp. Of these, only three samples, all collected from the Chiese river, were Lp2 ST1455.

The detailed investigation or inspection included:
* Environmental investigation was undertaken immediately and water samples were collected from private homes, municipal water systems, cooling towers and the river. Overall, 533 environmental water samples were analysed and 34 were positive for Lp. Of these, only three samples, all collected from the Chiese river, were Lp2 ST1455. If and how the river water could have been aerosolised causing the LD cases remains unexplained.

The case definition used for the cohort study is based on the EU case definition for Legionella pneumophila, which includes the following criteria: (1) resided in Brescia province; (2) presented with clinical symptoms of pneumonia; and (3) had laboratory confirmation for Legionella with at least one diagnostic test, according to the EU case definition [15].
Risks factors identified during the investigation were diabetes, cardiopathy, or chronic, or autoimmune or immunosuppressive diseases.
The contamination event spanned from the end of August to the first half of October 2018.

Immediate actions taken to mitigate the effects of contamination included:

* Disinfection of all industrial and non-industrial plants that might give rise to aerosols
* A correct use of the Chiese river water was recommended, taking into account periods of drought and guaranteeing the minimum vital flow for the ecological balance of the river itself
* European Legionnaires’ disease Surveillance Network was promptly informed by email in order to identify LD cases among European citizens who had travelled in the epidemic area.

Real-time PCR and serology were used to diagnose cases. Culture examination was carried out using agar plates with buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE-\u03b1; Thermo Fisher Scientific, Altrincham, United Kingdom (UK)) and selective antibiotic medium Modified Wadowsky\u2013Yee (MWY) with BCYE growth supplement (Thermo Fisher).
Lp.
The local health authority decided to enact a regional law aimed at implementing a mandatory notification of cooling towers, as recommended by the national Legionella guidelines.
Mandatory notification of cooling towers was implemented as a preventive measure to prevent future contamination events.

The age demographics of the individuals mentioned within the text are as follows:
* Median age of cases was 60.6 years (range: 19-91 years).

responses: The event occurred on June 11, 2014.
The contamination event took place at a private college in northwest China.

The contamination event was an acute gastroenteritis outbreak that occurred at a private college in northwest China in June 2014. The outbreak affected 629 students (range: 17-27 years, average 21.3 years) and two teachers, with symptoms including non-bloody watery diarrhea, stomach ache, nausea, and vomiting. The duration of illness ranged from 1 to 7 days. Eight of 18 water samples were disqualified. Thirty-four norovirus (NoV) RNA-positive samples were identified from 48 stool-related samples, including four GII.6 and five GI.6 strains. The risk ratios associated with wells one and two were 1.66 and 1.49, respectively, and the RR associated with living in north dormitory building one was 2.59. The study also detected bacterial and viral contamination in water and fecal samples, including EPEC and EAEC DNA from patient stool specimens and water samples from well one; two EAEC strains and one EPEC strain were isolated from patient stool specimens.

R\u00f8ros

The contamination event was a waterborne outbreak of campylobacteriosis in R\u00f8ros, Norway. The outbreak was suspected to be caused by untreated tap water from a groundwater source, and chlorination was started on May 11th. Campylobacter was isolated from patients' stool samples, and a dose-response relationship was observed in daily consumed glasses of tap water among randomly selected household members. No single event was identified as the cause of contamination, but several events that might have caused pressure fall and influx of contaminated water into the water distribution system were observed.
The text does not specify what triggered the contamination event.

The investigation confirmed a waterborne outbreak of campylobacteriosis in R\u00f8ros. Although no single event was identified as the cause of contamination, this outbreak illustrates the vulnerability of water distribution systems. Good quality source water alone is not enough to ensure water safety. For a better risk management, more focus should be put on the distribution system security.

The contamination event was first discovered on Monday 7 May 2007 when the municipal medical officer in R\u00f8ros notified the Norwegian Institute of Public Health (NIPH) about 10 patients with gastroenteritis who had consulted R\u00f8ros municipal health centre during the weekend.

Holt\u00e5len, which has a different water source, was used as a control city. We conducted telephone interviews to gather data on illness from all household members. One randomly selected household member was asked about detailed exposure history. The regional hospital laboratory tested patients' stools for enteropathogens. Campylobacter isolates were typed by AFLP for genetic similarity at the Norwegian Institute of Public Health. Local authorities conducted the environmental investigation.

Dushanbe, Tajikistan

The contamination event described in the passage occurred in Dushanbe, Tajikistan from January to June 1997. During this time, there were 8901 cases of typhoid fever and 95 deaths reported in the city. Salmonella serotype Typhi isolates tested were found to be resistant to most commonly prescribed antibiotics for typhoid fever treatment. The Ministry of Health advised that all drinking water be boiled, and the city government prohibited street vending of food and beverages. A case-control study found that drinking unboiled water was associated with an increased risk of typhoid fever. Fecal coliform contamination was found in tap water samples, and equipment failure, lack of chlorination, and back-siphonage in the water distribution system led to contamination of drinking water. After chlorination and coagulation were begun at the treatment plants and a water conservation campaign was initiated to improve water pressure, the incidence of typhoid fever declined dramatically.

Laboratory investigation. Blood and stool samples from patients with suspected typhoid fever at two Dushanbe hospitals were examined for Salmonella Typhi by standard methods [7]. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing using the disk diffusion method [8] was performed on 29 SalmonellaTyphi isolates obtained during routine surveillance from patients at hospitals throughout Dushanbe.

The contamination event took place in Cabool, Missouri.

The contamination event described in the passage occurred in Cabool, Missouri in December 1989 through January 1990. The event involved an outbreak of Escherichia coli 0157:H7 (EC0157) infections in residents of or visitors to Burdine Township. The contamination was caused by water from an unchlorinated water supply system that was damaged during extreme cold weather. The water system experienced freezing of lines or meter failure, and two large water mains broke on December 23 and 26, respectively. The contamination led to an increase in cases of bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps among residents, with 86 cases reported in total, including 4 deaths. The investigation revealed that the water system was not chlorinated, and the contamination was likely due to the failure to chlorinate the water supply during repairs.

responses: The contamination event occurred during a week-long holiday.
The contamination event took place in a district with limited laboratory support.

The contamination event involved a multi-organism gastroenteritis outbreak in a district with limited laboratory support due to disruption of routine monitoring and chlorination of the water supply system during a week-long holiday. The main water tank and pipes were rusted, and 13 out of 19 water samples tested positive for total Coliform (1-920 colony-forming units (CFU)/100 ml) and E. coli (1-720 CFU/100 ml). Chlorine levels were below 0.2 ppm in seven of the nine samples. Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli, Enteroaggregative E. coli, and norovirus were detected in human specimen samples.
The contamination event was triggered by disruption of routine monitoring and chlorination of the water supply system during a week-long holiday.
The contamination source was identified as the main water tank and pipes, which were rusted and had inadequate chlorination levels.

The investigation included collecting stool samples from patients for culture and PCR testing, inspecting and cleaning the main water tank and pipes, and collecting water samples from various points outside of the routine sampling points. The investigation also involved informing the public about safe water consumption practices and hygiene practices to prevent household transmission, and advising them not to use pools if they had gastroenteritis-related symptoms to prevent secondary infections.

Worcester city and two nearby towns in a semi-rural area of England, UK

The local water company received a considerable increase in complaints from the public concerning an unusual taste and odour in the drinking water in Worcester city on Friday afternoon. Initially unidentified organic chemical contaminants were detected in very low concentrations in the consumer drinking water leaving the water treatment works at Barbourne in Worcester where water is abstracted from the River Severn. People in Worcester were advised through local media releases from 12.25 pm on Friday not to drink the water and this advice was extended to include affected areas south of Worcester in the afternoon and evening. An estimated 160 000 people were living in the affected area and bowsers were deployed to provide an emergency water supply throughout Worcester city and affected towns and villages. The public were advised they could drink the water again at 5.15 pm. on Saturday after toxicology advice which confirmed that chemicals in this class were not expected to be harmful to health.

responses: The contamination event occurred in early spring (March 20-April 7, 1985).
The contamination event took place in a southern Ontario town.

The contamination event described in the passage occurred when meltwater entered one or more municipal wells in a southern Ontario town, resulting in the contamination of the town's drinking water supply with Campylobacter jejuni. The contamination was first detected on March 20 and 27, when marginal levels of fecal coliforms were detected in two separate locations in town. However, it wasn't until April 3 that all but one of the 12 sampling sites indicated heavy contamination, with levels ranging from 20 to 220 fecal coliforms per litre. On April 7, one well with a level of contamination greater than 600 fecal coliforms per litre was shut down, and chlorination of the town's water supply and a 'boil water' order were instituted. The outbreak of gastroenteritis in the town began on April 8, with the medical officer of health being informed of an increase in cases of gastroenteritis being seen in the emergency department of the town's only hospital.

G. lamblia cysts

The Epidemiology Division, Vermont Department of Health, Burlington, investigated an outbreak of diarrheal illness in 1986 in a residential trailer park consisting of 44 trailers and 122 residents located in rural Vermont. The investigation began after three park residents with laboratory-confirmed G. lamblia infection were reported within 2 days to the state health department; only one case of giardiasis had been reported from the same town during the previous 3 years. All park residents were interviewed in detail between 28 and 30 May 1986 regarding food and water consumption and gastrointestinal symptoms and again between 16 and 26 June to ensure that all ill persons had been identified. A case of outbreak-related giardiasis was defined as a trailer park resident who had G. lamblia cysts identified in stool or who reported three or more loose watery stools per day lasting 5 or more days between 1 April and 28 June 1986. Five days of diarrhea was required to meet the case definition to exclude persons with sporadic illness caused by common bacterial or viral pathogens, which is usually of shorter duration (2). Stool specimens collected in 10% Formalin were examined for G. lamblia cysts by the Formalin-ether concentration method (14). Stool specimens were not examined for cryptosporidia. The residue obtained by pumping 150 gallons (ca. 568 liters) of untreated park water through a wound Orlon filter (minimum pore size, 1 Fsm) was kindly examined for G. lamblia cysts by Judith F. Sauch at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Laboratory, Cincinnati, Ohio, using sequential immunofluorescence-phase-contrast microscopy (13). Park water also was tested for coliform bacteria by standard methods (1). All 122 park residents completed questionnaires. One or more stool specimens were obtained from 71 (58%) residents; two or more were obtained from 18 (25%) of these. Thirty-seven (30%) residents had a case of outbreak-related giardiasis: 23 residents had G. lamblia cysts detected in stool, and an additional 14 residents had diarrhea lasting 25 days but either their stools were not tested or cysts were not identified. The peak number of cases occurred 2 weeks before the initial interviews and extended over a period of 2 months (Fig. 1). Case residents resided in 23 (52%) of the 44 trailers, and there was no apparent clustering of cases in any portion of the park. The attack rates for males and females were similar. Eight (21%) of 38 residents aged <20 years and 29 (35%) of 84 residents aged .20 years met the case definition.

The article mentions that "levels of serum antibody to G. lamblia, particularly IgA, may be useful in determining exposure to G. lamblia-contaminated water and illness from G. lamblia during waterborne outbreaks of diarrheal illness." This suggests that testing for antibodies in the blood may be a useful tool for identifying individuals who have been exposed to Giardia lamblia and may be at risk for developing giardiasis in the future.

The contamination event was caused by a large outbreak of norovirus (NoV) gastroenteritis in Lilla Edet, Sweden in 2008. The outbreak was associated with consumption of municipal drinking water and resulted in about 2400 (18.5%) of the 13000 inhabitants becoming ill. Although NoVs were not detected in water samples, coliphages were identified as a marker of viral contamination.

The outbreak affected approximately 27,000 inhabitants and was characterized by a rapid onset and high attack rate, especially among young and middle-aged persons. The outbreak was caused by inadequate microbial barriers at the municipal water treatment plant, which failed to remove or inactivate Cryptosporidium oocysts in the raw water. The patients and some symptom-free coworkers were asked about the food and water they took in the past few days, and their attendance at the workplace. In addition, information on the source of drinking water was also obtained from the canteen managers of these three workplaces. It was also reported that the two factories and the construction site shared the same water supply system, and the construction site was at the terminal of the water supply system where a breakage of water pipes occurred a few days before the gastroenteritis outbreak. In addition, 39 coworkers at the construction site who always drunk purified bottled water were not sick.

The contamination event occurred when an external plumber connected the washwater pipe with the drinking water pipe at the sewage plant of a suburban municipality of Zurich, Switzerland, resulting in highly pressurized washwater flooding the drinking water system. This operating error was facilitated by the fact that the pipes of these two systems were indistinguishable because the drinking water system was not labelled. The alerted sewage plant manager quickly detected the operating error, restored the system, and informed the emergency organization of the canton of Zurich. The population of the municipality was alerted the same day in the late evening, and a boil-water notice was issued. Flushing of the main drinking water pipes by opening hydrants at the sewage plant and the surrounding area was initiated and continued for two days. Water samples from the possibly affected area were repeatedly collected to identify the extent of microbiological contamination as well as to assess the effect of flushing. Despite the measures taken, several cases of acute gastroenteric diseases were reported by a local newspaper on 12 February.

responses: The contamination event occurred between June 2013 and September 2014.
Abruzzo region (Central Italy)

The contamination event described in the passage involves monophasic variant of Salmonella enterica subspecies enterica serovar Typhimurium (monophasic S. Typhimurium) with antigenic structure 1,4,[5],12:i:-, which was found to be of increasing importance in Europe. In Italy, monophasic S. Typhimurium represented the third most frequent Salmonella serovar isolated from human cases between 2004 and 2008. In 2013-2014, a total of 206 human cases of salmonellosis were identified in Abruzzo region (Central Italy), with sole resistance to nalidixic acid, which had never been observed in Italy in monophasic S. Typhimurium, neither in humans nor in animals or foods. Epidemiological, microbiological and environmental investigations were conducted to try to identify the outbreak source.

responses: The contamination event occurred in March 1998.
Heinävesi, Finland

The contamination event occurred in March 1998 in Heinävesi, Finland, when an outbreak of gastroenteritis occurred due to Norwalk-like virus (NLV) genogroup II (GGII) in the municipal water supply. The virus was detected in untreated water, treated water, and tap water samples using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). The chlorination of the water supply was inadequate, leading to the survival of the virus in the water. The outbreak resulted in 1700-3000 cases of acute gastroenteritis and was associated with the consumption of municipal tap water.
The inadequate chlorination of the municipal water system triggered the contamination event.

responses: The contamination event occurred in April 1985.
The contamination event took place at Stafford District General Hospital.

The contamination event occurred at a large hospital in Stafford, England, where an outbreak of Legionnaires' disease occurred in April 1985. The outbreak was associated with the hospital's air conditioning plant, specifically the cooling water system, which contained the epidemic strain of Legionella pneumophila, serogroup 1, subclass Pontiac. The contamination likely occurred when an aerosol containing legionellae was generated in the U-trap below the chiller unit, which cooled the air entering the outpatient department (OPD). Nearly one-third of hospital staff had legionella antibodies, suggesting that they may have been exposed to low doses of contaminated aerosol over several months.

responses: The contamination event occurred in 2001.
The contamination event took place in Sheridan County, Wyoming.

The contamination event involved a waterborne Norovirus outbreak in Sheridan County, Wyoming in 2001. The outbreak occurred at a snowmobile lodge in the Bighorn Mountains and resulted in 70 ill persons, including several hospitalizations. The investigation identified the water supply of the lodge as the source of the contamination, which was confirmed through laboratory analysis. The environmental health assessment component of the investigation uncovered several underlying environmental factors that contributed to the contamination of the water supply, including rapid expansion of the lodge's facilities without adequate wastewater systems, poor soil and geologic conditions for onsite wastewater disposal, and a lack of treatment or disinfection in the drinking water system.

The text states that heavy precipitation and increased pumping of wells to satisfy higher demands probably facilitated the contamination of the drinking water wells by causing greater movement of wastewater through the soil and underlying bedrock.

responses: The contamination event occurred in May 2009.
Gosaba block, Sundarban area, West Bengal, India

The contamination event described in the passage occurred after Cyclone Aila hit the Gosaba block in the Sundarban area of West Bengal, India, in May 2009. The storm surge caused flooding in residential areas, damaging the piped water supply system and submerging ponds and tube wells with saline water. The affected villagers had to drink water from non-submerged ponds, which led to an outbreak of acute watery diarrhea. The outbreak started in the fourth week of May and lasted until August 2009, with two peaks in the second and fourth weeks of June. The median age of the case patients was 25 years, and 486 (45%) were female. The attack rate among 0-4-year-olds was higher than among other age groups. The villagers broke the repaired water pipelines to draw water nearer to their houses and used plastic/polythene to close the broken pipeline after use. Piped water was not tested regularly to check its quality, and two tap-water specimens collected during the study had coliform counts of 1600 and 1800 MPN/100 ml. Water collected from stored water specimens in affected households had coliform counts ranging from 1800 to 220 MPN/100 ml. Open-air defecation among children was common practice, and villagers had a belief that the stool of children was non-infectious. The block authority provided medical camps, daily chlorination, and health education regarding the danger of breached water pipelines and chlorine treatment at the household level, which led to a gradual decrease in incidence and the end of the outbreak in the fourth week of August.
The event that triggered the contamination event was the breaking of water pipelines near houses by villagers for easy access to water.
The origin of contamination was identified as faecal contamination of drinking water.
The contamination event was first discovered when two probable case patients had Vibrio cholerae El Tor Ogawa isolated from their rectal swabs.
The study did not provide enough information to determine the exact number of individuals exposed to the contaminant.
The study found that 1076 probable case patients and 14 deaths (attack rate 44/10 000) were identified.
The attack rate for this outbreak was 44/10 000 individuals exposed.
The study reported 14 deaths associated with the cholera outbreak in Gosaba block, West Bengal, India.
Vibrio cholerae El Tor Ogawa was isolated from two of five probable case patients’ stool specimens.
Diarrhea, nausea, severe dehydration, abdominal cramps, vomiting

The initial actions taken to investigate or inspect the event were:
1. Matched case-control study was conducted and rectal swabs and water specimens were collected.

The investigation included collecting rectal swabs and water specimens from probable case patients and conducting a matched case-control study. The study also involved collecting information regarding recent changes in the case definition, surveillance and population size, as well as interviewing random samples of case patients and abstracting medical records to collect information regarding demographic characteristics, signs and symptoms, and drinking water sources. Additionally, the study found that the villagers had broken the repaired water pipelines to draw water nearer to their houses and that water collected from piped water and stored water specimens had coliform counts above 1000 MPN/100 ml.

The case definition used for the cohort study was acute watery diarrhea, defined as three or more loose stools per day with severe dehydration admitted to any healthcare facility among residents of Gosaba block of any age between May and August 2009.

The risk factors identified during the investigation were:
1. Non-chlorinated piped water
2. Contaminated drinking water
3. Open-air defecation among children
The contamination event spanned from the fourth week of May to the fourth week of August 2009, which is approximately 4 months.

2. Chlorination at household level.
3. Educating villagers regarding the danger of breached water pipe connections.

The contamination event took place at the well for the water supply, which was located close to the main building (10-20 m from the nearest building; see Fig. 1).

The contamination event was caused by norovirus and occurred at a summer camp in western Norway in July 2002. The outbreak started with four visitors who vomited and experienced diarrhea and stomach pain lasting approximately 1 day. The well for the water supply was located close to the main building and was drilled at a slight angle towards the buildings. The ground was composed of rock, with limited coverage in the area. The water pipelines were located in the same trench as the sewage pipes. Sewage was collected in a two-chamber septic tank located 50 m from the well. The septic tank was emptied approximately twice a year. Leakage and breaks had previously been observed around the tank. The effluent from the septic tank was discharged through a pipeline out into the sea. Some blockage of the sewage was suspected, as 'bubbling' occurred when the toilets were flushed. The outbreak investigation found that drinking water and taking showers at the camp-site were significant risk factors for illness. Norovirus was identified in 8 out of the 10 stool samples analysed, and indicators of faecal contamination were found in samples from the private untreated water supply. The summer camp ended on 21 July, and the water supply was closed on 24 July.
The contamination event was triggered by the construction work involving blasting in the ground when the chapel was built some years ago.
The origin of the contamination was identified as the private untreated water supply.

Arizona, USA

The contamination event described in the passage occurred when faecal coliforms contaminated the water supply at a resort in Arizona, USA. The contamination was traced back to a deep water well that remained contaminated even after prolonged pumping. The outbreak of gastroenteritis affected nearly half of the resort guests, with symptoms including abdominal cramping, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. The mean incubation period was 41 hours and symptoms persisted for an average of 48 hours. The highest attack rate occurred on April 29-30, and there were no differences in attack rate by age, sex, race, or visitor group. Drinking tap water from the resort's well was significantly associated with illness, and the risk of illness increased significantly with the number of glasses of water consumed.
The contamination event was triggered by effluent from the resort's sewage treatment facility seeping through fractures in the subsurface rock directly into the resort's deep well.
The origin of the contamination was traced back to the deep water well, which remained contaminated even after prolonged pumping.
